title: Lesson 14: Comparing the Properties of Protons, Neutrons, and Electrons
content:
Lesson 14: Comparing Protons, Neutrons, and Electrons

A Final Look at the Atom's Building Blocks

We've discovered the three tiny particles that build everything in the universe. But what exactly makes them different?

Our journey through the atom is almost complete! We've met the three fundamental particles: the positive proton, the neutral neutron, and the negative electron. We know where they live and what their basic jobs are. In this final lesson, we will put them all side-by-side to create a clear "stat sheet" that compares their most important properties—their charge, mass, and location—so you have a perfect summary of everything you need to know about the building blocks of matter.

The Three Sub-Atomic Particles: A Head-to-Head Comparison

Let's break down the key features of each particle.

Proton (p⁺)

  • Charge:Positive (+1). It carries one unit of positive electrical charge.
  • Mass:Heavy (~1 u). It has a relative mass of 1 atomic mass unit and contributes significantly to the atom's total mass.
  • Location:Inside the nucleus. It is tightly packed in the atom's central core.

Neutron (n)

  • Charge:Neutral (0). It has no electrical charge at all.
  • Mass:Heavy (~1 u). Its mass is almost identical to that of a proton.
  • Location:Inside the nucleus. It is found alongside the protons.

Electron (e⁻)

  • Charge:Negative (-1). It carries one unit of negative electrical charge.
  • Mass:Negligible (~1/2000 u). It is so light that its mass is usually ignored when calculating atomic mass.
  • Location:Outside the nucleus. It revolves around the nucleus in specific energy shells.

Visualizing the Properties in an Atom

Let's put it all together in one diagram. Here is a model of a Lithium-7 atom, showing how the properties of the particles determine the structure.

Final Summary Table

Property Proton (p⁺) Neutron (n) Electron (e⁻)
Charge +1 0 -1
Relative Mass 1 u 1 u ~0 (1/1840 u)
Location Inside Nucleus Inside Nucleus Outside Nucleus

This table neatly summarizes everything we have learned about the atom's fundamental particles and how they come together to form the building blocks of our universe.

Lesson 14: Questions & Answers

1. Compare the properties of electrons, protons, and neutrons. Fill in the following table.

ParticleChargeMassLocation
Proton
Neutron
Electron
ParticleChargeMassLocation
Proton+1~1 uNucleus
Neutron0~1 uNucleus
Electron-1~0 uOrbits

2. Which sub-atomic particle is NOT found in the nucleus?

Correct Answer: The electron.

Protons and neutrons are located inside the nucleus, while electrons revolve in orbits outside the nucleus.

3. Which particle has a positive charge? Which one has no charge?

  • Positive Charge: The proton (p⁺).
  • No Charge: The neutron (n).

4. Which two particles have almost the same mass?

The proton and the neutron.

Both have a relative mass of approximately 1 atomic mass unit (u). The electron is much lighter.

5. Which particle has a mass that is considered "negligible" when calculating the mass number?

Correct Answer: The electron.

Its mass is only about 1/1840th (or ~1/2000th) of the mass of a proton or neutron, so it's too small to significantly affect the total mass.

6. What is the one thing that electrons and protons have in common, even though their signs are opposite?

They have the same magnitude (or size) of charge.

A proton's charge is +1, and an electron's is -1. The value is "1" for both; only the sign is different. This is why one proton can perfectly balance the charge of one electron.

7. True or False: Neutrons contribute to an atom's mass but not to its charge.

True.

Neutrons have a mass of ~1 u, so they add to the mass number. But they have a charge of 0, so they do not affect the overall electrical charge of the atom.

8. Which particle's count determines the atomic number (Z)?

The proton.

9. An atom's valency and chemical reactivity are determined by which sub-atomic particle?

The electron.

Specifically, the valence electrons (those in the outermost shell) determine how an atom will bond and react.

10. Arrange the three particles from heaviest to lightest.

The correct order is:

  1. Proton / Neutron (they have approximately the same mass).
  2. Electron (much lighter than the other two).

11. A standard hydrogen atom contains no neutrons. Is this possible? If so, which particles does it contain?

Yes, this is possible. It is the most common isotope of hydrogen (Protium).

A standard hydrogen atom consists of only **1 proton** in its nucleus and **1 electron** orbiting it.

12. Which two particles are responsible for the overall mass of an atom?

The proton and the neutron.
exercises:
Lesson 14: Exercises

1. Identify the Particle

I am found in the nucleus, have a mass of approximately 1 u, and carry a positive charge. Who am I?

Proton

2. Identify the Particle (Part 2)

I am found outside the nucleus, have a negative charge, and my mass is negligible. Who am I?

Electron

3. Identify the Particle (Part 3)

I am found in the nucleus, have a mass of approximately 1 u, and have no charge. Who am I?

Neutron

4. True or False?

A proton is approximately 2000 times lighter than an electron. (True / False)

False.

It's the other way around. A proton is approximately 1840-2000 times **heavier** than an electron.

5. The Location Game

Which two sub-atomic particles are found in the same region of the atom?

Protons and Neutrons.

Both are found inside the nucleus.

6. Charge Check

If you add the charge of one proton (+1) and one electron (-1) together, what is the resulting charge?

The resulting charge is 0.

This balance is why neutral atoms have an equal number of protons and electrons.

7. Odd One Out

Which particle is the "odd one out" in terms of its mass?
Proton, Neutron, Electron

The Electron.

Protons and neutrons have a similar, heavy mass, while the electron's mass is very small (negligible).

8. Odd One Out (Part 2)

Which particle is the "odd one out" in terms of its charge?
Proton, Neutron, Electron

The Neutron.

Protons and electrons have electric charges (+ and -), while the neutron has no charge (it is neutral).

9. Find the Contributor

Which particle is solely responsible for determining the atomic number (Z) of an atom?

The Proton.

10. Two Truths and a Lie

Which of the following statements is a LIE?

  1. Neutrons are found in the orbits around the nucleus.
  2. Protons have a positive charge.
  3. Electrons are much lighter than protons.

The lie is A.

Neutrons are found inside the nucleus. Electrons are found in the orbits.

11. Missing Vocabulary

A proton and a neutron can both be called a ____________ because they are found in the nucleus.

Nucleon

12. Role Call

Which particle is most directly involved in chemical bonding and reactions?

The Electron.

The exchange or sharing of valence electrons between atoms is what forms chemical bonds.

13. Visual Comparison

Look at the particle icons below. Match the name to the particle.

Particle A

Particle B

Particle C

A = Proton, B = Electron, C = Neutron.

Note how the electron icon is smaller to represent its negligible mass.

14. True or False?

An atom's identity is determined by the particle with no charge. (True / False)

False.

An atom's identity is determined by the proton (which has a positive charge). The neutron has no charge.

15. Final Summary Question

If an atom contains 1 proton, 1 neutron, and 1 electron:

  1. What is its overall charge?
  2. What is its mass number?
  • Overall charge: 0 (The +1 from the proton and -1 from the electron cancel out).
  • Mass number: 2 (1 proton + 1 neutron).
intros:
Lesson 14: Comparing Protons, Neutrons, and Electrons

A side-by-side look at the three fundamental particles that build our world.

Intro 1: Meet the Team

Every great team has players with different roles. What are the roles of the players on "Team Atom"?

Throughout this unit, we've been introduced to the three fundamental players that make up every atom. Each one has a very specific role on the team. The **Proton** is like the team captain; its count determines the team's name and identity. The **Neutron** is the strong, silent defender; it adds mass and helps keep the team's core (the nucleus) stable. The **Electron** is the fast, energetic forward; it's always moving and is responsible for all the interactions with other teams (chemical reactions).

To truly understand the atom, we need to know the specific properties of each player. In this final lesson, we will put them all side-by-side and compare their defining characteristics: their mass, their charge, and their location on the team.

Getting to know the complete roster of Team Atom.

Intro 2: The Building Blocks

You have three types of building blocks. How are they different, and how do they fit together?

Imagine all matter in the universe is built from just three types of LEGO-style blocks. To be a master builder, you need to know everything about these three blocks: how much they weigh, what their "connector type" (charge) is, and where they belong in the structure.

Our three atomic building blocks are the **proton**, the **neutron**, and the **electron**. Two of them are heavy and live in the center, while one is super light and flies around the outside. Two of them have electrical charges (one positive, one negative), while one has no charge at all. By comparing these simple properties side-by-side, we can fully understand how they combine to create the incredible diversity of elements we see in the world.

The three simple blocks that build a complex universe.

Intro 3: A Tale of Three Particles

We've followed their discovery, now let's get to know them. Who are the proton, the neutron, and the electron?

Our journey through the atom has been a story of discovery. We first met the **electron**, the tiny, negative particle that revealed atoms were divisible. Then we met the **proton**, the heavy, positive particle that gives an atom its core identity. Finally, we solved the mystery of the missing mass by discovering the **neutron**, the proton's heavy but neutral twin.

Now that the full cast of characters has been introduced, it's time for the final roll call. We'll bring them all on stage together for a grand finale, comparing their key features—charge, mass, and location—to create a complete "cheat sheet" that summarizes everything we need to know about these fundamental particles.

Taking a final bow with the stars of the atomic show.

Intro 4: By the Stats

How do you compare two athletes? You look at their stats! How do we compare the "atomic athletes"?

In the world of atoms, protons, neutrons, and electrons are the key players. And just like sports stars, they each have their own "stat card" that lists their most important properties. We can compare them based on three key statistics.

First, their **charge**—are they positive, negative, or neutral? Second, their relative **mass**—are they heavy or light? And third, their **location**—are they found in the dense center or in the space around it? In this lesson, we will create the final stat card for each particle, giving us a clear and complete summary of who they are and what they do.

Comparing the stats of the three atomic champions.

Intro 5: A Final Review

We've learned all the pieces of the puzzle. Now let's lay them out one last time to see the full picture.

Our entire study of atomic structure has led to this point. We now know that atoms are made of three fundamental particles: the proton, the neutron, and the electron. We know where each one lives inside the atom and how they combine to give each element its unique identity and mass.

As a final review of this chapter, it's time to put everything together. We will create a definitive comparison chart that lists the properties—relative mass, charge, and location—of each particle. This will serve as the ultimate summary and will solidify your understanding of the basic building blocks of all matter.

The grand summary of everything inside the atom.
